channel.title: Write that blog!
channel.description: Monthly dissection of engineering blog posts. Take a hint, get inspired, and write your own already.

item.title: A disappearing Service Processor
item.description: It's a bug hunt post with FPGA mentioned at least 7 times. No more recommendation needed.

item.title: Do Not Optimize Away
item.description: An interesting take on using the blackbox trick for microbenchmarks, or actually not using it.

item.title: Prediction: AI will make formal verification go mainstream
item.description: A prediction that hopefully comes true. Since almost everyone adores TLA+, and yet almost nobody is capable of writing a single correct line of it, perhaps we really need to offload formal verification to AI.

item.title: Your intellectual fly is open
item.description: A much needed call to stop posting LLM-generated content everywhere, because it shows. AI is great for many things, but not that. Have confidence in your own writing!

item.title: Why We Built Lightpanda in Zig
item.description: List of reasons for picking Zig over other system languages to build a browser for agents. Quite a standard collection of Zig's advantages, accompanied by nice short code snippets.

item.title: In defense of lock poisoning in Rust
item.description: An educational essay on the advantages of poisoning. In this particular case the poison is used in a homeopathy-style therapy, to prevent more serious issues from happening.

item.title: Imgur Geo-Blocked the UK, So I Geo-Unblocked My Entire Network
item.description: Beautiful tutorial on how to selectively route only specific websites through VPN, while keeping the rest of your network fast. Especially useful in the age of geo-blocking everything.

item.title: Assert in production
item.description: Good conclusions from the Cloudflare unwrap fiasco. tl;dr your production code should crash more, not less, especially if the alternative is running in a defective state. Much better to suffer from a few hours of downtime than chasing your leaked personal data in the darkest corners of the Internet.

item.title: Intel is listening, don't waste your shot
item.description: This article dares you to share brutally honest feedback with hardware vendors, for everyone's benefit. (And admits it is easier said that done.) Interesting perspective from an author who has been on both sides of those meetings with vendors.

item.title: Assertions are not the problem; your verification process is
item.description: High quality rant following all the opinions stated online after the Cloudflare fiasco. Read the whole thing if you would like to learn why, quoting, "However, all the arguments are wrong."

item.title: Cloudflare outage on November 18, 2025
item.description: Lesson learned: unwrap() is evil. Jokes aside, the article is a very detailed and prompt post-mortem report from a worldwide crash.

item.title: How quake.exe got its TCP/IP stack
item.description: Ever-entertaining author of Game Engine Black Books delivers again. This time it's a history lesson on how Quake gained a networking stack and why third-party companies were involved. Fascinating.

item.title: I Built a Synth for My Daughter
item.description: A full guide on how to cook your own hardware to your kid's delight. Includes lots of great resources to start working closer to electrical circuits as well as 3D design and printing. Super strongly recommended (no daughter required, although highly recommended as well).

item.title: The Write Last, Read First Rule
item.description: A story of how to make multiple distributed systems consistent by ordering the operations the right way. It also acts as a cautionary tale of what happens if you order the operations the wrong way (don't).

item.title: You Should Write An Agent
item.description: A call to write agents, with an embedded mini-tutorial. You should write an agent yourself! Even if just to have more fuel to hate generative AI. Chances are though, that you'll appreciate the things a deceptively simple loop can do.

item.title: Indexing sparse vectors with Turso
item.description: Now that the "vector database" hype is near its end, the world is in the "let's add vectors as first-class citizens to existing databases" stage. The article explains Turso's sparse vector indexing implementation and measures how all of its flavors and configurations perform.

item.title: I’m writing another book!
item.description: He’s writing another book!

item.title: Zig's New Async I/O (Text Version)
item.description: Zig's interesting take on how to implement I/O asynchrony and concurrency. Also, why the two are distinctly not the same thing, especially in Zig's implementation.

item.title: Corrosion
item.description: Fly.io's story of building a reliable service discovery system. Contains lots of educational cautionary tales, as well as lots of useful links.

item.title: How I Reversed Amazon's Kindle Web Obfuscation Because Their App Sucked
item.description: A beautiful tale of working through layers of DRM absurdity just to read a book in peace. Reverse engineering at its finest.

item.title: I am sorry, but everyone is getting syntax highlighting wrong
item.description: A philosophical piece on how to implement syntax highlighting in a way that does not hurt human eyes. I also admire a creative way of using the word "diarrhea" as a paragraph header.

item.title: How to check for overlapping intervals
item.description: The article starts with an introduction to something every other programmer rediscovered 17 times -- how to simplify the check for overlapping intervals. However, it also extrapolates the idea to two dimensions, which is a very nice pattern to remember.

item.title: How we found a bug in Go's arm64 compiler
item.description: Very informative bug hunt! Dives deep into the intricacies of arm64 architecture, where a deceivingly simple addition is not always encoded as a single opcode...

item.title: Tokenization from first principles
item.description: As a fellow CS336 "LLMs from Scratch" course hacker, I am deeply biased to like this post more -- it is a very good start for anyone interested in training large language models. On top of a very good introduction to what tokenizing is, the article also sums up one of the novel approaches -- superBPE. Well worth reading.

item.title: 2x Faster Hashes on AWS Graviton: NEON → SVE2
item.description: Comparison of various SIMD extensions, performed on Graviton instances. Nice opportunity to catch up on latest ARM improvements.

item.title: Cuckoo hashing improves SIMD hash tables (and other hash table tradeoffs)
item.description: A very thorough writeup on cuckoo hashing -- a genius CPU-cache-and-SIMD-friendly approach to hash tables.

item.title: Cancelling async Rust
item.description: Do not get your hopes up just yet -- async Rust is not cancelled as a whole. The article dissects the asynchronous destructors problem that most async frameworks have, one way or the other. In Rust, there exists a concept of "cancel safety" I was not really aware of. The concrete example of mutating state under a Tokio mutex really helped me grasp the idea!

item.title: How we scaled raw GROUP BY to 100 B+ rows in under a second
item.description: A longish (but well worth the time) summary of what makes ClickHouse GROUP BY fast. It also explains how to achieve massive parallelism, but still be able to correctly merge the state to return a coherent result. Nice.
Perfect title in the conciseness category. The article is also as concise as the title promises. It sums up where AI-assisted programming currently shines and fails respectively.

item.title: Turning Billions of Strings into Integers Every Second Without Collisions
item.description: Very practical post! A walkthrough on how to efficiently produce billions of UUIDs significantly faster than a sequential generator, and while avoiding the birthday problem. Nice trick to remember for managing data at large scale.

item.title: Eliminating Cold Starts 2: shard and conquer
item.description: Part II of Cloudflare's cold start lag elimination series, started with https://blog.cloudflare.com/eliminating-cold-starts-with-cloudflare-workers/ . This time, Cassandra-style consistent hash ring makes sure their workers are properly collocated. Requests are routed to servers that likely already host the same worker. Nice.

item.title: how AWS S3 serves 1 petabyte per second on top of slow HDDs
item.description: Nice description of how AWS casually distributes a single file over 20k hard disks so that its effective read concurrency is 20k. That, and a couple of other techniques to make S3 operate efficiently at its enormous scale.

item.title: Processes and Threads
item.description: High quality interactive post: processes and threads explained on a made-up CPU with a made-up architecture. Nicely explains the core (pun intended) concepts.

item.title: Obscure feature + obscure feature + obscure feature = bug
item.description: An amusing story on how using enough layers of C++ template metaprogramming eventually leads to hitting compiler bugs. Not fixed yet, as far as I see, as compilers move at their own pace.

item.title: %CPU Utilization Is A Lie
item.description: Periodic reminder that capturing complex metrics like "CPU utilization" with a single number is often impossible. In this article, hyperthreading is pointed out as a major contributor to "50%" utilization reports, when it is in fact closer to 100%.

item.title: Inside vLLM: Anatomy of a High-Throughput LLM Inference System
item.description: A detailed introduction into vLLM. It is very expert-friendly though. I can tell, because I am not one, and I get slightly confused by every other paragraph. Very educational nonetheless!

item.title: Big O
item.description: At this point it's pretty much muscle memory to include samwho's newest post in the digest. This time it visualizes Big O notation for computational complexity. Perhaps not groundbreaking for computer science graduates, but really useful to explain the importance of complexity to everyone else!

item.title: Optimizing our way through Metroid
item.description: Unique opportunity to learn fuzzers and deterministic simulation in action, while travelling back in time all the way to the GameBoy™ years. Brilliant. I also admire the genius blog rendering system where the "footnotes" become "side notes," printed right next to the main text.

item.title: Without the futex, it's futile
item.description: A thorough dissection of what futex (fast userspace mutex) is, why it is useful, and how to build other locking primitives on top of it. The article also serves as a sample and review of The Art of Multiprocessor Programming book, and was inspired by Phil Eaton's book club.

item.title: Inside ClickHouse full-text search: fast, native, and columnar
item.description: Full tutorial on full-text search. Includes lots of theory accompanied with visualizations and code snippets. Also, showcases how ClickHouse-specific approach makes it even faster, e.g. by making it column-friendly.

item.title: We Rewrote the Ghostty GTK Application
item.description: Lessons learned from yet another rewrite of Ghostty terminal emulator. The most interesting bits are actually about Zig (the language), and the fact that its compiler was able to detect the vast majority of memory safety bugs. All that without being Rust!

item.title: Zig’s Lovely Syntax
item.description: An opinionated piece on Zig's syntax choices. Inspirational, especially for people considering a new language.

item.title: Anubis.
item.description: This is a kind of article that makes you (or at least me) think "wow, I also assumed Anubis just worked perfectly, without actually verifying it with numbers like this guy did". Brilliant, and brings up very reasonable doubts if this system actually prevents AI scraping bots from accessing the website, or maybe it just mildly annoys users with older smartphones.

item.title: How Turso made connections to SQLite databases 575x faster
item.description: Part I: a study of a known performance bottleneck in SQLite when a database stores lots of tables. Part II: a showcase of how to elegantly fix the bottleneck and make sure opening new connections is smooooth and scales well regardless of the total number of tables stored.

item.title: Resizable structs in Zig
item.description: A technical deep dive into Zig language features. With a clever use of metaprogramming and Zig's approach to reflection, it is possible to get something that *looks* like a variable-sized struct, even though it is not contiguous in memory. Nice to know.

item.title: How we Rooted Copilot
item.description: A short story on convincing a large language model to jailbreak itself. Good for getting the basics on how to try and get some extra features off all the new AI products!

item.title: Why continuous profiling is the fourth pillar of observability
item.description: Datadog on continuous profiling -- how it works, why it's useful, how can it help you. Comes with a short history lesson on the art of profiling too.

item.title: How we tracked down a Go 1.24 memory regression across hundreds of pods
item.description: A successful hunt for memory usage regression in a new Go release. Includes lots of tips on how to profile Go memory in general. It's also part 1 of a miniseries. For part II, see https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/engineering/go-swiss-tables/

item.title: OpenZFS Bug Ported to Zig
item.description: Masterpiece variation on a bug hunt post, with the mystery gets solved in 1 minute. Also, zig flexing.
